author: @lanacionpy
title: La Nación / Peña afirma que es inaceptable la ratificación de los resultados en Venezuela
text: El presidente de la República, Santiago Peña, se pronunció a través de redes sociales manifestando su rechazo hacia la ratificación de los resultados en Venezuela, sin que haya existido una revisión de los mismos. El Tribunal Supremo de Justicia de dicho país asegura que Nicolás Maduro fue el ganador en los comicios del 28 de julio. “Lamentamos profundamente la decisión del Gobierno de Venezuela de avanzar en la ratificación de resultados electorales que no reflejan la voluntad del pueblo venezolano. Es inaceptable pretender validar ganadores sin que exista una revisión exhaustiva e independiente de los votos”, aseveró el mandatario. La sentencia del Tribunal Supremo, a través de su presidenta Caryslia Rodríguez informó este jueves 22 de agosto que se ha revisado el material entregado por la autoridad electoral y que este coincide en que Maduro ganó las elecciones, de esta forma, el actual jefe de Estado venezolano continuará otros seis años en el cargo. [Lea también: Presentan proyecto de minibiblioteca ANR-Lee, para seccionales del país](https://www.lanacion.com.py/politica/2024/08/22/presentan-proyecto-de-minibiblioteca-anr-lee-para-seccionales-del-pais/) La falta de credibilidad en los resultados electorales desataron una serie de manifestaciones en distintos puntos de Venezuela, además se registraron arrestos arbitrarios a la ciudadanía movilizada y también a referentes de la oposición, quienes pidieron que se transparenten los comicios y se muestren las actas electorales. Peña fue parte del pronunciamiento desde República Dominicana, donde junto con otros mandatarios, cancilleres y ministros, elevaron un pedido por el cese de las detenciones arbitrarias y exhortaron a respetar los principios democráticos y los derechos humanos. “Ningún país de Latinoamérica debe retroceder en su avance hacia una democracia cada vez más fortalecida”, manifestó en dicha oportunidad. [Le puede interesar: Lapidario informe de auditoría a la gestión del PLRA en la era Efraín Alegre](https://www.lanacion.com.py/politica/2024/08/22/lapidario-informe-de-auditoria-a-la-gestion-del-plra-en-la-era-efrain-alegre/)

author: Dylan Guenther
title: Wrestling: #4 Nebraska Hits the Road For Weekend Sweep Through the Mitten State
text:
After a brutal start to the Big Ten schedule against #5 Minnesota and #1 Penn State, the 4th-ranked Huskers will make a weekend road trip through the Mitten State to face #16 Michigan and Michigan State.
Nebraska will take on the Wolverines Friday night at 6 p.m. (live on the B1G Network) before facing the Spartans Sunday at Noon (streaming on B1G+).
first B1G road test
— Nebraska Wrestling (@HuskerWrestling)[pic.twitter.com/i2AoAeVGNz][January 21, 2025]
After going 1-1 against two of the best teams in the conference, Nebraska comes in as a battle-tested unit and the heavy favorite in both duals this weekend. There are a few matchups where the Wolverines could be considered favorites, but the Spartans are likely outmatched at almost every weight if Nebraska uses its full starting lineup.
After a brutal three-dual stretch to start the season — a 24-9 loss to #7 UNI, a 21-13 win over the Gophers, and a 31-7 loss at the hands of Penn State — Nebraska could be in the mood to rest some starters against some of these lesser opponents. I’ll mention below if there are any backups or freshmen that could make the trip and hit the mat.
Weight-by-Weight Breakdown
Rankings according to FloWrestling
125 pounds
Nebraska’s #7 Caleb Smith has had a really challenging season — his four losses have come to guys ranked #4, #5, #6 and #20. He owns wins this season over #8, #11 (twice), #12, #13 and #19.
Say what you want, but Caleb Smith goes out there and scraps against anyone and everyone. He’s 12-4 this year and just went through a tough start to the calendar year. I would anticipate that Nebraska could kill two birds with one stone by allowing a freshman (or a couple) to fill in to give Smith a break against two opponents that are not currently ranked, granting those freshmen valuable experience in a dual on the road.
Both redshirt freshman Alan Koehler (12-5) and true freshman Kael Lauridsen (7-3) are options here. Still under a redshirt, Lauridsen can wrestle in two more “events” and keep it. Koehler is 1-1 this season in duals, while Lauridsen is 1-0. This starting spot will belong to one of these two guys next season.
Regardless of who takes the mat, they’ll likely face Michigan’s Christian Tanefeu and Michigan State’s Caleb Weiand. Nebraska should be favored no matter which of the three goes out there.
Tanefeu is a junior who is 7-6 on the year but coming off a major-decision win against Maryland. He’s 10-17 for his career.
Weiand is a redshirt freshman with a 9-6 record this year. He went 0-2 at Midlands and lost his only match against a ranked opponent by major decision.
133 pounds
After a rough start to the year, Nebraska’s #12 Jacob Van Dee has been on fire in January, picking up three ranked wins in a row — 5-0 over #21 Julian Farber of UNI, 5-1 over #13 Tyler Wells of Minnesota, and a 14-7 win over #7 Braeden Davis of Penn State. He’s now 8-5 on the year.
Nebraska could also use true freshman Omar Ayoub here. Ayoub, who is 4-1 on the season, was a Top-100 recruit coming out of high school as a two-time Ohio state champion.
I kind of expect Van Dee to get both matches though because he’s young and just needs more matches to improve. He will likely see Michigan’s Nolan Wertanen and Michigan State’s Tristan Lujan this weekend.
Wertanen is 5-9 this year and has lost his last six matches. He took over after Michigan lost then-#4 Dylan Ragusin for the year due to injury earlier this season. Van Dee has two career wins over Ragusin, including a 10-4 decision this year at CKLV.
Lujan is a senior with a 47-47 career record. He’s 3-4 this season after qualifying for NCAAs last season.
Van Dee by a mile in both matchups.
141 pounds
Much like Van Dee, Nebraska’s #6 Brock Hardy has gone through an absolute gauntlet so far this January — a 7-5 loss to #5 Cael Happel of UNI, a 12-10 win over #8 Vance Vombaur of Minnesota, and an 8-7 loss to #3 Beau Bartlett of Penn State.
Another Husker veteran who could maybe use a break this weekend, Hardy will likely wrestle against Michigan but could take off the dual against the Spartans, letting junior Blake Cushing get in there.
Michigan offers one of the weekend’s premier matchups with Hardy taking on #9 Sergio Lemley. A sophomore, Lemley is 12-4 this year, including a 4-2 loss to Vombaur last time out. Last season, Hardy and Lemly met three times with Hardy winning two of them.
Michigan State will likely send out Jaden Crumpler, a redshirt freshman with a 4-9 record on the year. Against four ranked opponents this year, Crumpler is 0-4 and gave up bonus points in three of those matches.
149 pounds
Coming off his huge win over then-#2 Shayne Van Ness of Penn State to be named the Big Ten Wrestler of the Week for the second time this season, Nebraska’s Ridge Lovett moved up from #5 in the country to #2. His only loss this year was a 6-3 loss in sudden victory to #1 Caleb Henson of Virginia Tech, the returning NCAA Champion.
Another week, another award.
— Nebraska Wrestling (@HuskerWrestling)[@RidgeLovett]is your[@B1GWrestling]Wrestler of the Week for the second time this season.[#ToughTogether]|[#GBR][pic.twitter.com/u79UFjtSos][January 23, 2025]
It’s possible that Lovett gets a rest day, so redshirt freshman Scott Robertson could make the trip as well.
Michigan will send out redshirt freshman #28 Dylan Gilcher, while the Spartans have Clayton Jones, also a redshirt freshman. Gilcher is 7-4 this year, while Jones is 3-7.
Lovett should mow through this weekend fairly easily.
As for a career statistic watch — Lovett currently has an 87-20 career record and needs 13 more wins to join the 100-win club at Nebraska. He’d be its 31st member.
157 pounds
Nebraska’s #5 Antrell Taylor fell this past weekend to Penn State’s #3 Tyler Kasak, but he has a chance at redemption this weekend.
Against the Wolverines, Taylor will face #16 Chase Saldate. Saldate pinned Taylor a few years ago when the young Husker was redshirting, but Taylor beat Saldate this year in Vegas 15-11. Saldate has lost three straight matches since CKLV, but it could still be another really entertaining match.
The Spartans have Braden Stauffenberg, a sophomore with a 3-10 record on the year. Taylor should make quick work of him.
165 pounds
Nebraska’s #9 Bubba Wilson returned this past weekend and lost via tech fall to #1 Mitchell Mesenbrink of Penn State. He’ll have the chance this weekend to get back in the win column.
With redshirt freshman Chris Minto showing a lot of promise in his limited action this year (he beat then-#9 Andrew Sparks in a dual and was ranked #13 the following week), they could share the lineup this weekend.
Michigan will send out redshirt freshman #18 Beau Mantanona, a top-shelf recruit a couple years ago. He’s 7-1 on the year with his only loss to #27 Noah Mulvaney of Bucknell. He’s come on recently with two ranked wins in a row over #19 Maxx Mayfield and #14 Sparks.
For Michigan State, DJ Shannon will take the mat. A senior, Shannon was an Illinois transfer who has a 24-39 career record. He’s 3-3 this year for the Spartans.
The Mantanona match will be tough for either Wilson or Minto, but the Michigan State matchup shouldn’t be too difficult.
174 pounds
Wrestling here for Nebraska is #15 Lenny Pinto, a junior who is 13-4 this year. He started 2025 with a pair of ranked wins but fell this past weekend to #2 Levi Haines of Penn State. Pinto’s 7-2 decision loss is the first non-bonus win of the season for Haines.
This weekend, Pinto will likely take the mat for both duals — against Michigan’s Joseph Walker and Michigan State’s Ceasar Garza. Walker is a senior who is 8-4 on the year, while Garza is a sophomore with a 10-7 record this year.
Pinto is a big favorite in both of these matches.
If Pinto does rest, look out for true freshman (redshirting) LJ Araujo. The top recruit for Nebraska in 2024, Araujo looks to be the real deal in the practice room. He’s 10-4 on the year after taking some lumps early on, but he still has just one event left.
184 pounds
Nebraska’s #7 Silas Allred has gone through a brutal stretch since the calendar turned over to 2025 — he’s lost three straight matches to #2 Parker Keckeisen (pin), #4 Max McEnelly (16-6 major) and #1 Carter Starocci (11-2 major).
Things get much easier this weekend with Allred getting set to take on Michigan’s #17 Jaden Bullock and Michigan State’s Lucas Daly.
Bullock is 8-7 on the year, but he's wrestled some top guys very close — dropping a trio of 4-1 decisions to #4 McEnelly, #6 Bennett Berge and #10 Jaxon Smith.
Daly is 9-8 this season but has been pinned by the two Top-10 opponents he’s faced.
This is the perfect weekend for Allred to bounce back and get into the win column again.
Nebraska could also bring redshirt freshman Ethan DeLeon for this weight. He’s 15-3 on the year with one dual loss against UNK and the rest in open tournaments.
197 pounds
Where some of the guys have a manageable path this weekend, some just do not, and #26 Camden McDanel is an example of that. McDanel has lost his last three matches to really tough guys — #12 Wyatt Voelker (6-4 decision), #10 Isaiah Salazar (8-0 major) and #4 Josh Barr (19-4 tech).
Things don’t get any easier this weekend with McDanel set to face #2 Jacob Cardenas of Michigan. After that, McDanel will take on Michigan State’s #23 Remy Cotton.
Cardenas is a two-time All-American who transferred this year from Cornell. He’s 11-0 on the year with his most recent 8-3 decision over Salazar his only non-bonus point victory. He's really good and in my opinion one of the few guys with a legitimate shot at making it to the NCAA final. It’s a tough matchup for the true freshman McDanel.
Cotton is no slouch either. A redshirt freshman, he’s 10-4 on the year and coming off a tech-fall win against Maryland. His losses haven’t been too bad either, so he’ll be a tough out.
McDanel will have his hands full this weekend, but I know he’s tough and will continue figuring things out as the season progresses.
285 pounds
Speaking of tough schedules, Nebraska’s #22 Harley Andrews just wrestled both #1 Gable Steveson and #2 Greg Kerkvliet in back-to-back weekends. He lost both matches via tech fall, but he did show flashes and didn’t back down to either man.
In fact, he shot up the rankings a few spots this week after losing to Kerkvliet 20-2, possibly because he scored a reversal on the returning NCAA champion. They were the first offensive points Kerkvliet has given up all season.
This weekend, Andrews will take on Michigan’s #10 Josh Heindselman and #33 Max Vanadia of Michigan State. Heindselman is a four-time national qualifier for Oklahoma before transferring to Michigan for his final season. He’s 14-1 on the year with his only loss a pin at the hands of the Olympic Champion Steveson.
Vanadia is a redshirt freshman who is 10-11 on the year. He's 0-2 in Big Ten duals and was pinned by Kerkvliet in under a minute.
Starting your Big Ten season 0-2 isn’t ideal, but I think Andrews deserves a pass based on his opponents. Now that he’s seen the best, maybe these other guys coming up won’t feel as tough for him. Look out for him to score some upsets before the postseason rolls around.

author: Nyamweru vfrago@gmail.com
title: Gorilla Building Is Redefining Commercial Construction and Roofing in Mississippi
text:
-- In a traditionally male-dominated industry, Gorilla Building stands out — not just for breaking barriers, but for building one of Mississippi’s most respected commercial construction and roofing companies. Founded in 1998 by Carol Wilson, this family-owned business has grown into a trusted name for commercial steel building projects, commercial and residential roofing, directional boring, commercial flooring, and luxury outdoor construction.
With the bold slogan “Built Strong. Built Right. Built by Gorilla Building,” the company is known for delivering durable, high-performance results — on time, on budget, and with zero compromise on quality. Their reputation is rooted in clear communication, jobsite discipline, and a commitment to doing every job right the first time.
As owner and founder, Carol Wilson remains actively involved in operations, ensuring every project meets Gorilla’s high standards. She brings decades of hands-on experience and a deep understanding of what it takes to run a successful commercial construction business in Mississippi. Her leadership has helped shape Gorilla Building into a name synonymous with reliability and professionalism.
Team members like Kolby Bex play a key role in upholding that reputation in the field. With a sharp eye for detail and a passion for craftsmanship, Kolby ensures every job — whether a roofing installation or a steel structure — is completed with precision and pride. “We don’t cut corners,” he says. “If we’re putting our name on it, it’s going to be built to last. We’ve built our reputation on that.”
That reputation has been earned through years of five-star reviews, word-of-mouth referrals, and long-standing relationships with clients across the state. Whether it’s residential roof replacement, steel building construction, or underground directional boring for utilities, clients return to Gorilla Building because they value the honesty, timelines, and consistently high-quality results.
Gorilla Building proudly installs Atlas Roofing shingles, manufactured right here in Mississippi. These premium shingles are produced in Meridian, MS, and are known for their durability, curb appeal, and long-term performance — making them a perfect match for Gorilla’s commitment to quality on every residential roofing project.
Led by Carol Wilson and her husband Todd, Gorilla Building continues to raise the bar for Mississippi construction companies. Todd holds an unlimited state builder’s license, brings decades of field experience, and manages all of the company’s digital marketing — blending traditional expertise with modern strategy.
One longtime client put it best:
“Todd and Carol are the real deal. Honest, hard-working, and always looking out for your best interest. They gave us advice we didn’t even know we needed — and it saved us time and money. You won’t find a more trustworthy team in this business.”
Together, Carol and Todd ensure Gorilla Building remains family-owned, hands-on, and deeply committed to doing things the right way. They’ve built not just a company — but a reputation for trust, quality, and long-term value.
With a skilled team, proven leadership, and a foundation built on integrity, Gorilla Building continues to lead Mississippi in commercial construction and roofing services — one project at a time.

Email: Send Email

author: Ian Kayanja
title: chevron-right
text: GEORGETOWN COUNTY, S.C. (WCIV) — A 17-year-old boy who faces charges in Ohio was arrested after fleeing the scene of a traffic accident, the Georgetown County Sheriff's Office said. The teenager was located in Myrtle Beach days after a driver refused to stop for a Georgetown County Sheriff's Office deputy in the Pawleys Island area leading to a collision. Law enforcement said that a second individual involved in the incident, Payton Baldridge, 19, has active warrants. [4 suspects, including 2 minors, involved in Georgetown Co. stolen car chase turned crash] GEORGETOWN COUNTY, S.C. (WPDE) — Two passengers were detained after a stolen vehicle pursuit in Pawleys Island on Monday... [Continue reading] On Monday, a vehicle reported as stolen in Ohio containing two males and two females was spotted by a deputy on Martin Luther King Drive in the Pawleys Island area. A chase resulted in an accident between the deputy and a civilian vehicle and a separate one-car accident by the suspects in the stolen car, law enforcement said. The driver and one male passenger in the stolen vehicle ran into the woods. Two female passengers were detained. The teenager will be sent back to Ohio to face charges.

author: archyworldyscom
title: Diagnosis of the "Damby Rushing accident" market accident
text:
The Perils of Cognitive decline: A Case Study in Road safety A recent incident in Seoul, South Korea, has brought the critical issue of cognitive decline and its impact on road safety to the forefront. On December 31st,2023,a 75-year-old driver,identified as Mr.A, lost control of his vehicle in a bustling traditional market, resulting in one fatality and 12 injuries.
The investigation revealed that Mr.A was traveling at a significantly higher speed than the posted 30 km/h limit, estimated to be between 60-70 km/h, when he collided with several fruit stalls and pedestrians. CCTV footage corroborated the police findings, showing no mechanical failure contributing to the accident.
Mr. A, though, displayed signs of memory impairment, claiming to have no recollection of the incident immediately after it occurred. He later recalled accelerating rapidly and applying the brakes too late, suggesting a potential lapse in cognitive function.
Prior to the accident, Mr. A had been diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) in November 2023. MCI is a precursor to dementia, characterized by subtle declines in memory and cognitive abilities, but individuals can still generally manage daily activities.
Despite the diagnosis,Mr. A had discontinued his prescribed medication in february 2023. This highlights a crucial point: while MCI is not currently grounds for mandatory driving license revocation in South Korea, it underscores the importance of proactive measures and individual responsibility.Further medical evaluations conducted after the accident revealed that Mr. A was likely experiencing early-stage Alzheimer’s dementia. He was later placed under medical care,emphasizing the need for complete assessment and management of cognitive decline in older adults.
This tragic incident serves as a stark reminder of the potential dangers posed by undiagnosed or untreated cognitive impairment. It underscores the need for:
Increased awareness: Educating the public, notably older adults and their families, about the signs and symptoms of MCI and dementia.
Early detection and intervention: Encouraging regular medical checkups and cognitive screenings for individuals at risk.
Responsible driving practices: Promoting safe driving habits and encouraging individuals with cognitive concerns to voluntarily refrain from driving.
Policy review: Exploring potential policy changes regarding driving licenses for individuals with MCI or dementia, balancing individual autonomy with public safety.
By addressing these issues, we can work towards creating a safer environment for everyone on the road.
Decoding the “Damby Rushing Accident” Market: A Comprehensive Guide to Diagnosis and Prevention
Understanding the “Damby Rushing Accident” Landscape The term “Damby Rushing Accident” refers to a category of accidents that frequently enough occur in high-pressure, time-sensitive environments. While “Damby Rushing” might not be an established industry term, it evokes a sense of hasty action, possibly leading to errors and misjudgments. This type of accident can manifest across various industries, including:
Manufacturing:
Construction:
Transportation:
Healthcare:
These industries share a common thread: the need for speed and efficiency often intertwines with the inherent risks of their operations.
Unveiling the Causes: A Multifaceted Approach The root causes of “Damby Rushing Accidents” are complex and multifaceted, frequently enough stemming from a combination of:
Organizational Pressure:
Company-wide goals, tight deadlines, and performance targets can create a culture of urgency, encouraging individuals to take shortcuts or prioritize speed over safety.
Human Error:
Fatigue, distraction, lack of training, and inadequate communication can considerably contribute to accidents.
Systemic Issues:
inadequate safety protocols, poorly designed workflows, and faulty equipment can create unsafe working conditions.
Cognitive Biases:
Our brains are wired to make quick decisions, but this can lead to cognitive biases, such as confirmation bias (seeking information that confirms existing beliefs) and overconfidence bias (exaggerating one’s own abilities). These biases can impair judgment and increase the risk of accidents.
Diagnostic Techniques: Pinpointing the Problem Accurately diagnosing the cause(s) of a “Damby Rushing Accident” is crucial for implementing effective prevention strategies.
Hear are some key diagnostic techniques:
Incident Inquiry:
A thorough investigation of the accident should be conducted, involving interviewing witnesses, analyzing physical evidence, and reviewing documentation.
Data Analysis:
Analyzing historical accident data can reveal patterns and trends, helping to identify root causes and high-risk situations.
Safety Culture Assessments:
Surveys, interviews, and focus groups can provide insights into the organization’s safety culture, identifying perceived risks, communication barriers, and safety-related attitudes.
Task Analysis:
breaking down complex tasks into smaller steps can reveal potential hazards or areas where human error is more likely to occur.
Ergonomic Assessments:
Evaluating the physical demands of tasks and the work environment can identify ergonomic factors that may contribute to accidents.
Effective Prevention Strategies: Building a Safer Future Effectively preventing “Damby Rushing Accidents” requires a multi-pronged approach that addresses both individual and organizational factors:
Cultivating a Strong Safety Culture: Fostering a culture where safety is paramount requires leadership commitment, clear communication, and employee empowerment.
Reducing Organizational Pressure: Implementing realistic deadlines, promoting work-life balance, and discouraging unrealistic performance expectations can reduce the pressure to cut corners.
Improving Training and Communication: Providing comprehensive safety training, regularly reviewing procedures, and encouraging open communication can equip employees with the knowledge and resources to work safely.
implementing Robust Safety Protocols:
Developing and enforcing clear safety protocols, including emergency procedures, can minimize risks and guide actions in critical situations.
Investing in Technology:
* Implementing technology solutions, such as wearable safety devices, real-time monitoring systems, and automated safety features, can further enhance safety.
